sentences.english: This is a story Spirit-Eagle told long ago.

sentences.original: êkot ê-kî-wîcihiwêt, mitâtaht ayiwâkês êh-ihtasiyit, ot êh-ntopayicik, ayâhciyiniwah ê-ntopayîstawâcik, êkwah wâhyaw êh-ayâcik ayahciyiniwah otaskiyihk, êkosi kîkisêpâ sipwêhtêwak, ê-waniskâcik.
sentences.text: êkota ê-kî-wîcihiwêt mitâtaht ayiwâkês ê-ihtasiyit ôta ê-nitopayicik ayahciyiniwa ê-nitopayîstawâcik êkwa wâhyaw ê-ayâcik ayahciyiniwa otaskiyihk êkosi kîkisêpâ sipwêhtêwak ê-waniskâcik
sentences.english: There where he went with a war party of some ten men or more on the war-path against the Blackfoot, when they were far into the Blackfoots' country, they got up one morning and started out.

sentences.original: êkwa kîtahtawêh ayahciyiniwak ês ê-kîh-nipahâcik mostoswah, êwakonih itohtêwak.
sentences.text: êkwa kîtahtawê ayahciyiniwak êsa ê-kî-nipahâcik mostoswa êwakoni itohtêwak
sentences.english: Presently they came to some buffalos which the Blackfoot, apparently, had killed.
sentences.footnote: LB on {itohtêwak}:  The Cree are the third person, subject of this last verb; hence the sentence should properly read {... ayahciyiniwah ês ê-kîh-nipahâyit ...}, with the Blackfoot in the obviative form.

sentences.original: êkosi êkwah kotawêwak, ê-wîh-mîciwâcik wiyâs, êh-mîcisocik.
sentences.text: êkosi êkwa kotawêwak ê-wî-mîciwâcik wiyâs ê-mîcisocik
sentences.english: So they made a fire, for they intended to make a meal, eating the meat.
They gathered buffalo-dung for fuel.

sentences.original: êkwah êkotah apwêwak, wiyâs êh-mah-manisahkik, êh-nah-nawacîcik, êkwah nîsoh ê-ispatinâyik êh-wâpahtahkik, ê-wîh-ntaw-âsawâpicik, nîso ê-sâkêwêcik.
sentences.text: êkwa êkota apwêwak wiyâs ê-ma-manisahkik ê-na-nawacîcik êkwa nîso ê-ispatinâyik ê-wâpahtahkik ê-wî-nitawi-asawâpicik nîso ê-sâkêwêcik
sentences.english: There they did the roasting, cutting slices of meat and making preserved meat; two of them, the while, ascending a rise in the land which they saw, to reconnoitre.

sentences.original: namoya iskw êh-mîcisocik, êwakonik kâ-natawahtâcik -- kîtahtawêh âstam itah ê-sakâsiyik misatimwah kâ-sâkêwêyit;
sentences.text: namôya isko ê-mîcisocik êwakonik kâ-nitawâhtâcik kîtahtawê âstam ita ê-sakâsiyik misatimwa kâ-sâkêwêyit
sentences.english: They had not yet eaten, when those scouts - suddenly on this side of a small grove some horses came forth;

sentences.original: kîtahtawêh ayahciyiniwah kâ-sâkêwêyit, êkwah êh-itâpicik, mîkiwâhpah ê-sâkamoyikih.
sentences.text: kîtahtawê ayahciyiniwa kâ-sâkêwêyit êkwa ê-itâpicik mîkiwâhpa ê-sâkamoyiki
sentences.english: soon a Blackfoot came forth; and when they looked that way, there the tops of some tents showed forth.
So they fled into the brush;

sentences.original: tapasîwak kônihk, sâkahikanis, êkotah pikoh kônah êh-apit, kwayask itah êyakonik nîso êyakonik kâ-ntawahtâcik.
sentences.text: tapasîwak kônihk sâkahikanis êkota piko kôna ê-apit kwayask ita êyakonik nîso êyakonik kâ-nitawâhtâcik
sentences.english: they fled on the snow, straight to a small lake that was all covered with snow, those two scouts.

sentences.original: êkwah ayahciyiniw sâkowêw, nêhih kâ-nâh-nawaciyit êh-wâpamât, êkwah owîcêwâkanah êh-nitômât.
sentences.text: êkwa ayahciyiniw sâkowêw nêhi kâ-nâh-nawaciyit ê-wâpamât êkwa owîcêwâkana ê-nitomât
sentences.english: The Blackfoot gave the war-whoop, when he saw those who were preparing meat, to call his comrades.

sentences.original: êkosi nêki nêhiyawak tapasîwak, mistah ê-pasahcâyik êkotah êh-itâmocik.
sentences.text: êkosi nêki nêhiyawak tapasîwak mistahi ê-pasahcâyik êkota ê-itâmocik
sentences.english: So these Cree fled, heading for a deep ravine.
The Blackfoot surrounded the Cree in the chase.

sentences.original: êkwah ôki kônihk kâh-kî-kwayasitêcik kisiwâk wâpamêwak ôhi ayahciyiniwah.
sentences.text: êkwa ôki kônihk kâ-kî-kwayasitêcik kisiwâk wâpamêwak ôhi ayahciyiniwa
sentences.english: Those who had gone into the snow, saw the Blackfoot from close by.

sentences.original: êkwah pimipiciwak êkotah cîki, iskwêwak ê-nitawi-kapêsicik êkotah.
sentences.text: êkwa pimipiciwak êkota cîki iskwêwak ê-nitawi-kapêsicik êkota
sentences.english: They moved their camp close by there; the women went along to camp there.

sentences.original: apisîs pikoh tawâw, osâm mistahi ê-pasahcâk, êkotah pîhcâyihk nêhiyawak êh-ayâcik, ê-nôcihihcik.
sentences.text: apisîs piko tawâw osâm mistahi ê-pasahcâk êkota pîhcâyihk nêhiyawak ê-ayâcik ê-nôcihihcik
sentences.english: There was only a small opening, so narrow and deep was the ravine in which the Cree stayed when they were attacked.

sentences.original: êkwah ôki mistahi mâkwaciwak, nipîhk êh-akocihkik.
sentences.text: êkwa ôki mistahi mâkwaciwak nipîhk ê-akocihkik
sentences.english: And these men were very cold, lying in the water.

sentences.original: êkosi kônah êh-pakonênâcik, êh-itâpicik, kisiwâk iskwêwah êh-pimohtêyit, mîkiwâhpah kisiwâk êh-cimatêyikih.
sentences.text: êkosi kôna ê-pakonênâcik ê-itâpicik kisiwâk iskwêwa ê-pimohtêyit mîkiwâhpa kisiwâk ê-cimatêyiki
sentences.english: When they made a rift in the snow and looked out, there were the women walking by and the tents standing near.
They heard the Blackfoot whooping.

sentences.original: êkwâ awah pêyak k-âkocihk kônihk, osîmah pêyak êkotah ayâyiwah, manitôwi-kihiw osîmah.
sentences.text: êkwa awa pêyak kâ-akocihk kônihk osîma pêyak êkota ayâyiwa manitowi-kihiw osîma
sentences.english: One of the men who were lying in the snow had a younger brother with the other group; Spirit-Eagle's younger brother it was.
“This noise of shooting is not as when quarter is shown.
Let us go there;
my brother is with them,” said Spirit-Eagle.

sentences.original: êkwah sâyiman ômisi itêw manitôwi-kihiwah : kiyâm êkâ wiyah.
sentences.english: Then Solomon spoke thus to Spirit-Eagle: “Better not.
For no one will tell the tale, if all of us are slain.

sentences.original: mâkah pimâtisiyahkoh, ômah ê-nîsiyahk kik-âcimonânaw, kîkinâhk takosiniyahkoh.
sentences.english: But if we live, we two, we shall tell the tale, when we reach our camp.

sentences.original: mâkah itohtêyahkoh, kahkiyaw nipahikawiyahkoh, nam âwiyak t-âcimôw nêtêh mîkiwâhpihk.
sentences.english: But if we go there and all of us are killed, no one will tell it there at home.
When we reach our camp, we shall tell the tale,” said Solomon.

sentences.original: moscis wâpamêwak ayâhciyiniwah êh-pâ-pasahkâpiyit, osâm kisiwâk êh-kapêsimostawâcik.
sentences.text: mosci wâpamêwak ayahciyiniwa ê-pâ-pasahkâpiyit osâm kisiwâk ê-kapêsimostawâcik
sentences.english: Plainly they could see even when a Blackfoot blinked his eyes, so close had they camped to them.
And they nearly were stepped on by the horses that came to drink.

sentences.original: aspapiwinah kikiskamwak misatimwak; pîsâkanâpiy otâpêwak ê-sakikwêpisocik.
sentences.text: aspapiwina kikiskamwak misatimwak pîsâkanâpiy otâpêwak ê-sakikwêpisocik
sentences.english: The horses had saddles on; they were dragging reins, being all bridled.

sentences.original: omis îtwêw sâyiman : têhcipayihotân ôkih misatimwak.
sentences.english: Thus spoke Solomon: “Let us throw ourselves on these horses.
No doubt they are bridled because they are swift.
They will not be able to catch up to us.”

sentences.original: êkosi ômisih itwêw manitôwi-kihiw : nama wiyah nika-kîh-nakatâw nisîm.
sentences.english: To this Spirit-Eagle answered thus: “I cannot leave my brother behind.

sentences.original: omah kâ-mâh-matwêwiyik êkotah aspin kîh-wîcihiwêw nisîm, itwêw manitôwi-kihiw.
sentences.english: Over yonder where we hear the shots, is where my brother has gone with the rest,” said Spirit-Eagle.

sentences.original: êkwah êh-pôn-âpihtâ-kîsikâk, kîtahtawêh omis îtwêw sâyiman : âta niwîh-kawacin; âta wiyah niyah nikah-pimâtisin, itwêw,
sentences.text: êkwa ê-pôn-âpihtâwi-kîsikâk kîtahtawê ômisi itwêw sâyiman itwêw
sentences.english: When noon had passed, Solomon spoke: “I am almost frozen to death; yet I shall live,” he said;
sentences.footnote: LB on {nikah-pimâtisin}:  I.e. “I feel sufficient mystic power in me to know that I shall live.”

sentences.english: “But as for you?” he said to Spirit-Eagle.

sentences.original: êkosi ômisi itwêw : niya mînah nikah-pimâtisin, itwêw manitôwi-kihiw;
sentences.english: Then he answered thus: “I too shall live,” said Spirit-Eagle;
“Do you perform first, Solomon.”
“Very well,” said Solomon;

sentences.original: omis îtwêw sâyiman : hâw, miscicâkanis, kikîh-isin.
sentences.english: thus spoke Solomon: “Come, Coyote, 'From close by shalt thou see me when thou art in danger of being slain,' saidst thou to me.
And Wind, 'From close by shalt thou see me, when thou art in danger of being slain,' saidst thou to me.
Thy blanket-robe I ask of thee;
I long for life,” spoke Solomon.
“So there; arise,” said he to Spirit-Eagle,
“let us flee.

sentences.original: êkâ wiyah ohcih âpasâpih, k-ôsêhcâk awasêwêyinih.
sentences.english: Do not look behind you when you pass the knoll.
I shall come close behind you.”

sentences.original: êkosi manitôwi-kihiw sêkisiw kita-pasikôt, osâm kisiwâk êh-ayâyit ayahciyiniwah;
sentences.text: êkosi manitowi-kihiw sêkisiw kita-pasikôt osâm kisiwâk ê-ayâyit ayahciyiniwa
sentences.english: Then Spirit-Eagle was afraid to stand up, for the Blackfoot were close at hand;

sentences.original: mâskôc nistomitanaw tahkoskêwin êkoyikohk mîkiwâhpah êh-ayâyikih, êwako ohcih sêkisiw.
sentences.text: mâskôc nistomitanaw tahkoskêwin êkoyikohk mîkiwâhpa ê-ayâyiki êwako ohci sêkisiw
sentences.english: because the tents were perhaps thirty steps away was why he feared.
“Come, arise now!”
Then Solomon kept close behind him.
They went to where a hill close by cut them off from sight.
They were drenched through.

sentences.original: êkwah nîpisiyah nântaw têpakohp misit êy-iskwâyikih, êkotah kisâtamwak.
sentences.text: êkwa nîpisiya nânitaw têpakohp misit ê-iskwâyiki êkota kisâtamwak
sentences.english: In a place where the willows were some seven feet high they stayed.

sentences.original: kîtahtawêh misi-yôtin; êwakonih sâyiman kâ-kîh-nitômât kita-pimâcihikot.
sentences.text: kîtahtawê misi-yôtin êwakoni sâyiman kâ-kî-nitomât kita-pimâcihikot
sentences.english: Soon a great wind blew; that was the one whom Solomon had called to save his life.
Accordingly he gave thanks.
There came a great fall of snow.
Then they lit a fire;
they undressed and dried their clothes.
It was very bad weather.

sentences.original: êkosi êkwah êh-tipiskâk, misatimwah kimotiwak, ayâhciyiniwah otêmiyiwah, aspapiwinah ê-kikiskamiyit.
sentences.text: êkosi êkwa ê-tipiskâk misatimwa kimotiwak ayahciyiniwa otêmiyiwa aspapiwina ê-kikiskamiyit
sentences.english: So when night came, they stole horses, the Blackfoots' horses, all saddled.
Then they fled.

sentences.original: êkwah oki nêhiyawak kâ-nôcihihcik, tapasîtân, itwêw pêyak.
sentences.text: êkwa ôki nêhiyawak kâ-nôcihihcik itwêw pêyak
sentences.english: As for those Cree who were besieged, “Let us flee,” said one.

sentences.original: êkwah ospwâkana oyaskinahêw; miyêw nâpêwah kita-nitonamiyit êh-tawâk itah.
sentences.text: êkwa ospwâkana oyaskinahêw miyêw nâpêwa kita-nitonamiyit ê-tawâk ita
sentences.english: Then he filled a pipe; he gave it to a man who was to look for an opening.
He came back:
“Over here is, to be sure, a small opening,” he said.
Then they made ready.

sentences.original: êkwah oskinîkiw-iyinîs otâhk ê-kaskâwikanêhoht, ê-wîh-ntawih-minihkwêyâhk nipiy, itwêwak nâpêwak.
sentences.text: êkwa oskinîkiwiyinîs otâhk ê-kaskâwikanêhoht itwêwak nâpêwak
sentences.english: And, as a young lad had been shot in the stomach, “We are only going to get a drink of water,” said the men.

sentences.original: êkwah awa nâpêsis ayih acosisah otinam.
sentences.text: êkwa awa nâpêsis ayih acosisa otinam
sentences.english: Then the lad took some arrows.
“I shall be able to go.

sentences.original: pêyak ayahciyiniw nika-nipahâw, itwêw awah nâpêsis kâ-wîh-nakatiht.
sentences.english: I shall kill a Blackfoot,” said the lad who was to be abandoned.
Then those men fled.

sentences.original: kotak nâpêw êh-pakocêhoht, âsay êh-miyâskahkik mîkiwâhpah, pitah nik-âyiwêpin; ispisohtêk, itwêw awah kâ-pakocêhoht.
sentences.text: kotak nâpêw ê-pakocêhoht âsay ê-miyâskahkik mîkiwâhpa itwêw awa kâ-pakocêhoht
sentences.english: Another man who had been wounded in the side, when they had already passed the camp, “Let me rest a bit; do you go on ahead,” said he who had been wounded in the side.

sentences.original: êkosi êyâpic anohc nam êskwa takosin.
sentences.text: êkosi êyâpic anohc nama êskwa takosin
sentences.english: To this day he has not arrived.
And they fled bare in the cold.
Thus two of these people were killed.

sentences.original: êkwah ayahciyiniwah mihcêt kî-nipahêwak; okimâwah mistahi kî-nipahêwak.
sentences.text: êkwa ayahciyiniwa mihcêt kî-nipahêwak okimâwa mistahi kî-nipahêwak
sentences.english: They had killed many Blackfoot; they had killed many chieftains.
And so they reached home;

sentences.original: mistahi kih-miyawâtamwak, osâm mihcêt ê-kîh-nôcihikocik ayâhciyiniwah.
sentences.text: mistahi kî-miyawâtamwak osâm mihcêt ê-kî-nôcihikocik ayahciyiniwa
sentences.english: they rejoiced greatly because they had been so close pressed by the Blackfoot.
That is all.

sentences.original: êkosi anah nêhiyâsis iskwêyâc wiyah kîh-nipahêw ayâhciyiniwah, ê-wîh-otihtinikot;
sentences.text: êkosi ana nêhiyâsis iskwêyâc wiya kî-nipahêw ayahciyiniwa ê-wî-otihtinikot
sentences.english: But as for that Cree lad, at the very last he killed a Blackfoot, as they were about to reach him;
one he killed at the very last.
Spirit-Spruce-Grove is the name of the place where they were besieged.
Greatly gifted with spirit power was Solomon; through this their lives were saved.
